meta.title: Embryologic derivatives: Gastrulation, neurulation, and the primary germ layers

content:
Introduction

The embryonic stage of fetal development, which occurs 3-8 weeks after fertilization (ie, weeks 5-10 of gestation), involves the differentiation of specialized tissues and organs from a single fertilized egg.  Key to this process are gastrulation and neurulation, which lead to the formation of the 3 primary germ layersâ€”ectoderm, mesoderm, and endodermâ€”and the subsequent development of the central nervous system.

Gastrulation



Gastrulation (

figure 1
) marks the beginning of the embryonic stage of development.  It is the process by which the blastocyst, a hollow ball of cells, reorganizes from a bilaminar disc into a trilaminar (3-layered) disc (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm), from which all tissues and organs are derived.  This process occurs during week 3 postfertilization and begins with the formation of the primitive streak, a structure that appears on the surface of the epiblast, the outer layer of the embryo.  Epiblast cells migrate downward through the primitive streak to form the mesoderm and endoderm layers.  A portion of epiblast cells also migrate cranially through the primitive node (the cephalic end of the primitive streak) to form a midline, mesoderm-derived cellular cord known as the notochord (
figure 2
).

Neurulation



The central nervous system develops via neurulation (

figure 3
) during the third and fourth weeks.  The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to differentiate into the neuroectoderm and form the neural plate.  As neurulation progresses, the edges of the neural plate elevate to form neural folds.  Formation of the neural tube (precursor to the brain and spinal cord) occurs as neural folds migrate toward the midline and fuse by the end of week 4 postfertilization.  Fusion begins in the cervical region and extends rostrally and caudally; the ends, or neuropores, close at the end of the fourth week.  During this process, neuroectodermal cells adjacent to the crest of the neural folds separate from the surface ectoderm to form neural crest cells.  Following neurulation and by the end of week 5 postfertilization, these neural crest cells migrate to distant sites and later develop into diverse tissues.

Germ layers and their derivatives

Ectoderm



The ectoderm is the outermost germ layer and differentiates into structures primarily associated with the nervous system and skin.  The ectoderm is composed of surface ectoderm, neural tube, and neural crest cells.



  • Surface ectoderm:  The surface ectoderm gives rise to the anterior pituitary as well as the epidermis and its appendages (eg, sweat glands):

    • Anterior pituitary (Rathke patch)
    • Lens and outer layer of the cornea
    • Inner ear sensory organs, olfactory epithelium
    • Nasal and oral epithelial linings, salivary glands
    • Epidermis, sweat and mammary glands
    • Anal epithelium below the dentate line
  • Neural tube:  The neural tube gives rise to neurons of the central nervous system and the neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary), retina, pineal gland, preganglionic autonomic fibers, astrocytes, and ependymal cells.
  • Neural crest:  Neural crest cells are multipotent, migratory cells that originate in the ectoderm at the margin of the neural tube and give rise to a diverse cell lineage, including the following:
    • Neural ganglia (eg, dorsal root ganglia, sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia, enteric ganglia cells), adrenal medulla (eg, chromaffin cells)
    • Melanocytes (melanin-producing cells)
    • Schwann cells; pia and arachnoid mater
    • Aorticopulmonary septum and endocardial cushions
    • Branchial arches (bones and cartilage)
    • Skull bones

Mesoderm



The mesoderm is the middle layer of the embryo.  It is divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral sections and gives rise to structures related to movement, support, and circulation (as well as the kidneys/ureters).



  • Muscles:  Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth
  • Connective tissue:  Bone, cartilage, blood, and lymph
  • Serosal linings:  Peritoneum, pleura, and pericardium
  • Cardiovascular and lymphatic systems:  Heart, blood vessels (eg, capillary endothelial cells), lymph nodes, spleen
  • Urogenital system:  Kidneys, ureters, internal genitalia
  • Adrenal cortex

Endoderm



  • The endoderm is the innermost layer of the embryo.  The endoderm gives rise to:
  • Structures derived from the inner lining of the primitive gut tube:  These include the gastrointestinal tract (esophagus, stomach, intestines) and the bulk of the liver and pancreas (outpouchings of the primitive gut tube).
  • Bladder and (most of) urethra.
  • Thyroid follicular cells (derived from the primitive tongue).
  • Parafollicular (C) cells:  Formerly thought to be of neural crest origin.
  • Thymus, parathyroids.
  • Middle ear epithelium.
  • Lungs:  Respiratory epithelium.

Some clinical correlates

Gastrointestinal system



The gastrointestinal system illustrates the interplay between the cell layers.  It is derived from components of each of the 3 layers:



  • Ectoderm:
    • The surface ectoderm gives rise to the oral epithelial linings and salivary glands.
    • The neural crest gives rise to neural ganglia, including enteric ganglion cells.  These cells are responsible for intestinal relaxation, and failure of neural crest cell migration to the distal colon during embryonic development leads to Hirschsprung disease.
  • Mesoderm:  The peritoneum and spleen are derivatives of the mesoderm, which also gives rise to the smooth muscle component of the intestinal tract.
  • Endoderm:  Gastrointestinal derivatives of the endoderm include the liver, pancreas, and epithelial lining.


Although most intraabdominal organs are derived from the endoderm, the spleen is unique because it is derived from condensed mesenchymal tissue in the dorsal mesentery.  Mesenchymal tissue arises from the mesoderm and is characterized by loosely associated cells surrounded by the extracellular matrix.

Nervous system



  • In humans, the notochord almost completely regresses, and its only major derivative is the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc.
  • Vertebrae are derived from the paraxial mesoderm.
  • Cutaneous neurofibromas (seen in neurofibromatosis type I) are benign nerve sheath neoplasms predominantly composed of Schwann cells, which are embryologically derived from the neural crest.
  • Exposure to a teratogenic medication (eg, folic acid antagonist such as valproic acid) during neurulation interferes with caudal neural tube closure and causes a neural tube defect (
    figure 4
    ).

Endocrine system



  • Unlike the adrenal cortex, which is derived from mesoderm, the adrenal medulla is a neural crest derivative.
    • Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor, arises from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, which are neural crest cell derivatives.
  • The anterior pituitary is derived from the Rathke pouch, an evagination of the surface ectoderm that lines the fetal oral cavity.  In contrast, the posterior pituitary (pars nervosa and pituitary stalk) is derived from the infundibulum, an extension of neuroectoderm from the diencephalon (
    figure 5
    ).
    • Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors arising from the Rathke pouch.  They occur commonly in children (eg, ages 5-14) and usually grow gradually over a period of years, causing slowly progressive symptoms (eg, optic chiasm compression leading to bitemporal blindness).
